page.title: 01 A General Description
page.content: This area is situated on the lower Western slopes of the Pennines as they make their descent to the flat Cheshire Plain below.It is an upland area of open countryside criss_crossed by drystone walls which divide it into numerous fields.It has a vegetation cover mainly of grassland except on the highest ridges and plateaux, where this gives way to heath and peaty moorland.Deciduous trees line the lower banks of the many streams and rivulets, and extensive coniferous plantations are to be found on the higher hillsides.The valley slopes are dotted with an ever increasing number of hawthorn bushes but the high windswept tops remain desolate and treeless.There is also the occasional pocket of bog identified by the clumps of tufted grass so typical of marshy land.
